course.subject: MECH
course.name: Aircraft Design
course.description: Students will work in teams to develop a conceptual design for a complete flight vehicle, using knowledge and skills acquired in the Aerospace Engineering Major curriculum. Specific considerations will include market conditions, mission requirements, aircraft size and layout, airfoil/wing geometry, aerodynamics, engine selection, airframe-engine integration, fuselage design, electrical and hydraulic systems, landing gear arrangement, flight stability and control, structures and materials, avionics and navigation systems, human factors, safety, manufacturing processes, and cost analysis. The teams will present their proposed designs via oral presentations and written reports.
course.prerequisites: MECH 1907 AND MECH 3640 AND MECH 3650
course.corequisites: MECH 3660 AND MECH 3670

reviews.author: An225 Mriya
reviews.title: The end of a beginning: MECH1907 Extra Stage
reviews.comment_content:
The course taught the preliminary aircraft design. Aircraft design is indeed a very complex and time-consuming process, so the course only covered the first steps using first-order estimation methods.

Contents:
1. Course introduction
2. Aircraft design overview
3. Preliminary weight estimation
4. Preliminary sizing
5. Aircraft configuration
6. Fuselage layout
7. Preliminary wing design
8. Preliminary weight balance
9. Stability analysis, empennage design (by Mr. Anthony Hays)
10. Landing gear design
11. Structures
12. Propulsion
13. Aerodynamic refinements
14. Cost analysis
15. Optimization and higher-order analysis

The course also placed strong emphasis on coding. Before taking MECH3620 one should have learnt the basics of Julia programming language in MECH3670. The course's tutorials would teach the full extent of Aerofuse, a HKUST developed first-order aircraft design analysis module.

To be honest, these first-order skills might not be that useful in real-life aircraft manufacturing industry unless you are posted to preliminary design departments (Professor Redonnet said Airbus indeed had a group of engineers work on using low-fidelity first-order analysis to get a first glance). However, if you intend to pursue a FYDP related to aircraft design (there is 2 for this year), the course's contents are definitely relevant and useful.
reviews.comment_teaching:
You should have probably known Professor Rhea Liem well. She's responsible for teaching the aerospace engineering curriculum's introduction (i.e. MECH1907) and the final course. Before the course, she asked us some concerns related to this course, and provided useful feedback/appropriate modifications in response to our concerns. She also vowed to create a more democratic course, in which she would let us to decide whether we would pay attention to some supplementary contents and videos or leave early. For more comments on Professor Liem, one can seem my review on MECH1907:

https://ust.space/review/MECH1907/view/hGz5chN5llYR7I1nC4svW240V97d01Mr

For the part of stability analysis and empennage design, Mr. Anthony Hays was in charge of the lectures. He was a British engineer who emigrated to and worked in the United States. As a native speaker his English was very clear, albeit he spoke a little fast. He may also held some academic conferences and took consultation in HKUST (this year it was hydrogen-propelled aircraft), in which his contents and advice may be useful to unconventional designs.

James Mingzhi Shihua, Aobo Yang and Arjit Seth were the course's TAs. The previous two were responsible for most weekly tutorials, while Arjit was responsible for introducing us to Julia coding and Aerofuse. All of them were helpful and responded to enquiries timely. As Aerofuse is a developing programming module, there could be some bugs within it. You are strongly encouraged to report irregularities when something went wrong despite double-checking!
reviews.comment_grading:
*Class participation: 5%
*Individual coding assignment: 10% (76%, mean 86.32%)
*Quizzes (x2): Each 5%
**(Quiz 1: 90%, mean 78.82%)
**(Quiz 2: 76.67%, mean 90.2%)
*Independent self study: 25% (91%, mean 83.02%)
*Aircraft design project: 50%
**Midterm review: 10% (90%, mean 83.41%)
**Final report and presentation: 40% (Never released per MAE practice)

Professor Liem did count on class participation, though it was not by roll calling. Questions asked in lectures and (especially) during midterm and final presentations were counted.

The coding assignment was similar to typical COMP course assignments by filling codes in the empty spaces of a Julia notebook file. The quizzes were similar to what one had experienced in MECH1907, in which multiple choice conceptual questions without requiring calculation was asked. They were take-home open-book quizzes, and we were given a week to finish them. Apparently I didn't excel that much in terms of them, but the nevertheless cost 20%.

The independent self study required student to either write an essay or record a video on an aircraft design or aviation/aerospace industry-related topic. Before we started off with them, Professor Liem would review and comment on our proposed topics. I wrote about a baka (⑨) bomb amidst the ongoing Ukrainian war and received a high score.

One can therefore see how important is your aircraft design project. In this semester we were required to design a mid-range business jet (not sure whether the topic would change in the future). The midterm review was significantly laxer than the final review, as it was intended to be a feedback session.

At the end I get an A for this course, which seems to be proportional to the course's great workload.
reviews.comment_workload:
Before mid-March, the project workload of MECH3620 wasn't that high apart with some assignments and quizzes, as we were not taught with more course contents yet. Once that turning point was passed, you would be facing with the workload of midterm review, independent self study, concurrent with the workload from other courses (most notoriously MECH3690).

Professor Liem told us to start working on the independent self study as soon as she approved your topic. This is indeed correct, as the first wave of lab reports in MECH3690 struck at approximately early March. While not much technical analysis can be done, establishing your topic's factual background and source analysis are important when you start the analysis later.

During the latter stage of the course, you would be working on more programming analysis. It was also the time when your group would prepare for Powerpoint for presentation. Depending on which part you did, running programs (especially true for optimization) could often be time-consuming, and a high-performance laptop is definitely a good companion. You should also note that the provided MADE collaborative server is a potato server that frequently crashed, so make sure you do frequent backups (a group lost all of their server files and backup files stored on the server), and avoid running large programs on the server.

Professor Liem provided a timetable listing out the suggested deadlines for each part of design, try your best to stick with it for time management.

reviews.author: 販冰兵
reviews.title: The most beautiful AE Professor atm 因爲得一個女AE Prof
reviews.comment_content:
Basically all about Aircraft Design.

Preliminary weight estimation
Preliminary sizing
Fuselage layout, configuration selection, design considerations
Preliminary wing design
Stability analysis
Preliminary weight and balance
Empennage design
Landing gear sizing and disposition
Structural loads and considerations
Propulsion system
Sizing refinements
Aerodynamic refinements
Cost analysis
Aircraft design in practice:  tradeoff and sensitivity studies, optimization, etc
reviews.comment_teaching:
Rhea is really nice and she explains everything in detail vividly so you will definitely learn a lot it you attend lectures. Though attendance is not required in this course, you will definitely benefit from not skipping classes since 女人好小氣 and some bonuses will be given to those who attended her class especially during midterm periods.

In the tutorials sections, she will sometimes hold the JET Talks series in which she will explain the stories behind some famous aircraft models (e.g. U2, SR-71, F117, etc)

Rhea will probably invite guest lecturers and they often are some very experienced person in the industry so I bet you won't want to miss those lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
This is a project-based course so you will at least get a pretty good grade if you put effort working on it.

Tho the margins for A range is narrow so if you aim for an A-/A/A+, you will need to work really hard (to find some very smart groupmates)
reviews.comment_workload:
This is a project-based course and you have to complete one individual term paper and one group design project.

For the individual term paper, students are encouraged to pick a topic related to aircraft design and/or airline industry and perform an independent study beyond what is taught in class.  Students then  need to  summarize  what  they  learn in  an  individual  term  paper,  including  the  background/motivation,  why  they  find  it  interesting,  analyses  of  the  effects  on  aircraft  design,personal  thoughts/opinions/analyses  on  the  selected  topic.   The  paper  must  include  some technical aspects as well; students need to present relevant and important facts and figures,and  cite  journal  articles/books/other  references  properly.   

For the group design project, you will be working in a group of around 5 students, students will work on a conceptual aircraft design.  There will be two options for the course project, each with the overall mission requirements given.  Each group, however, still needs to perform the relevant market  research and  literature  review.   Based  on these  requirements,  the  group  then  performs the conceptual design and performance analysis of the selected aircraft configuration.

P.S. And if you really want to design something good, you will have to go through A LOT of extra stuff and read many textbooks and related materials that is beyond the scope in class.

reviews.author: LuQ
reviews.title: Fun course, but very heavy group project work
reviews.comment_content:
It's basically a summary of all things you've learnt so far, which is why this course has so many prerequisites. During lectures, she basically give a summary of what we all already know, but also adding how the actual design process is like, using the knowledge we already have. On top of that, she'll also introduce some nice aircrafts that show how design factors to much of the properties of the aircraft (Blackbird, U2, F117).

The project is largely related to the content she teaches, but it is the TA who introduces how can we implement code into the design process.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Rhea always strive to improve her style of teaching. She likes to joke during class, and even shows that she's friendly with many of the students. If you took 1907, she'll likely remember you by name. She's also very responsive after class and by email.

For 3 of the lectures, she has a guest lecture through zoom, Tony Hays a very-experienced aircraft engineer in the design field. He even introduced a bit about his career journey. He also gave us his contact to ask him any questions, even concerning the project, which was very helpful.

TA also is extremely helpful during tutorials, email, or through announcements.
reviews.comment_grading:
The main grading allocation is the project (with final report and presentation), then there's individual assignments (1 coding assignment, 1 small homework and 2 online quiz), and an individual term paper.

50% Group project (Report + Progress report + Presentation)
25% Individual term paper
15% Individual mini-assignments
10% Class participation and group dynamic

I got some bad groupmates, so the progress reports weren't as good as I hoped it was, nor the final report which I know could be better. But in the end I got B+. Rhea knew my group situation and has group peer review, so I guess the grade I got is quite optimistic
reviews.comment_workload:
Very high concerning the group project, which is essentially designing your own scenic aircraft. Hope you have groupmate who knows aircrafts really well, or else the guessing game is going to be much more painful.

Based on the aircraft you want to design, the more unusual the concept is, the more research you need to do. I know a group did an electric aircraft, they did a ton of research already during the beginning of the semester because it is a bit out of AE students's scope from what we've learnt so far.

Moreover Rhea makes us do progress update reports so that we won't have to do last-minute work as much. Plus she could give some feedback if there's some concerning issues about our report. But this is what makes it very heavy, as I only met my groupmates online, it's difficult to find a time to discuss and make sure everyone does their work. Each progress reports is due about 2-3 weeks then the next one is up.

I've got terrible groupmates, I mean they don't do anything, me and 1 other guy managed to finish most of the work. So obviously for me it was very heavy as my groupmates 'stopped working' since early in the semester.

Individual assignments and term paper was relatively simple and easy to do, just make sure the formatting is alright for the term paper. The individual term paper is any topic of our choice that is closely related to aircraft design. Rhea will require a simple topic proposal before she approves, then we can start writing. We got about 1.5 month to finish it.
